OptimalBinningWoE 0.3.3
  • Reference

Classical, robust, and independence correlations

OBCorr.Rd

Function to compute, pairwise, classical, robust, and distribution-free correlations between all numeric variables of a data.frame. Implements literature-based versions of:

  • Pearson (linear, parametric);

  • Spearman (ranks with midranks);

  • Kendall tau-b (corrects for ties);

  • Hoeffding's D (U-statistic for independence, 30x scale as in Hmisc);

  • Distance Correlation (dCor) by Székely–Rizzo–Bakirov (2007);

  • Biweight midcorrelation (bicor, WGCNA style, with scaled MAD and \(c=9\));

  • Percentage Bend correlation (pbcor, Wilcox, with default \(\beta=0.2\)).

The implementation prioritizes pairwise complete observations, numerical robustness, and performance (OpenMP), while preserving formal definitions accepted in the literature and reference packages (e.g., Hmisc, energy, WGCNA, WRS2).

Usage

OBCorr(df, method = "all", threads = 0L)

Arguments

df

data.frame with at least two numeric/logical variables. NAs are handled pairwise.

method

String with one of the values:

  • "pearson", "spearman", "kendall";

  • "hoeffding", "distance";

  • "biweight", "pbend", "robust" (= biweight + pbend);

  • "alternative" (= hoeffding + distance);

  • "all" (default).

threads

Integer for OpenMP control (0=auto according to hardware_concurrency()).

Value

data.frame in long format, with columns:

  • x, y: variable names in the pair;

  • Statistics according to method: pearson, spearman, kendall, hoeffding, distance, biweight, pbend.

Details

1) Classical correlations

Pearson. For valid pairs \((x_i,y_i)\), the correlation is $$r = \frac{\sum_i (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_i (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_i (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}.$$ Ranges in \([-1,1]\) and captures linear dependence.

Spearman. Computes Pearson between midranks \(R_i,S_i\). Preserves \([-1,1]\) and detects non-linear monotonicity.

Kendall tau-b. Based on concordant/discordant pairs, corrects for ties in margins: $$\tau_b = \frac{C - D}{\sqrt{(C + D + T_x)(C + D + T_y)}},$$ with \(T_x,T_y\) accounting for ties (including joint ties).

2) Hoeffding's D (implementation following SAS/Hmisc)

Measures \(\int (F_{XY}-F_XF_Y)^2\,dF_{XY}\) and is consistent against arbitrary dependence (includes non-monotonic). Uses univariate midranks \(R,S\) and bivariate rank \(Q\) (counts \(\leq\) with weights for ties). The form used in Hmisc and SAS (30× scale) is: $$D = 30 \cdot \frac{(n-2)(n-3)\sum (Q-1)(Q-2) + \sum (R-1)(R-2)(S-1)(S-2) - 2(n-2)\sum (R-2)(S-2)(Q-1)}{n(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)(n-4)},$$ requiring \(n\geq 5\). Under continuous margins, \(D\in[-0.5,1]\) (typically \([0,1]\) without ties).

3) Distance correlation (dCor, 2007)

With distance matrices \(A_{ij}=|x_i-x_j|\), \(B_{ij}=|y_i-y_j|\), performs double centering: $$A^\circ_{ij} = A_{ij}-\bar{A}_{i\cdot}-\bar{A}_{\cdot j}+\bar{A}_{\cdot\cdot},\quad B^\circ_{ij} = B_{ij}-\bar{B}_{i\cdot}-\bar{B}_{\cdot j}+\bar{B}_{\cdot\cdot}.$$ Defines $$\mathrm{dCov}^2 = \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i,j} A^\circ_{ij}B^\circ_{ij},\quad \mathrm{dVar}_X = \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i,j}(A^\circ_{ij})^2,\quad \mathrm{dVar}_Y = \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i,j}(B^\circ_{ij})^2,$$ and the distance correlation $$\mathrm{dCor} = \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{dCov}^2}{\mathrm{dVar}_X\mathrm{dVar}_Y}}\in[0,1],$$ being 0 iff independence (under conditions).

4) Biweight midcorrelation (bicor)

With median \(\tilde{x}\) and scaled MAD \(\widehat{\mathrm{MAD}}_x=1.4826\cdot\mathrm{MAD}\), defines \(u_i=(x_i-\tilde{x})/(c\widehat{\mathrm{MAD}}_x)\), \(c=9\). Weights \(w_i=(1-u_i^2)^2\) if \(|u_i|<1\) and 0 otherwise. Computes $$\mathrm{bicor}(x,y)=\frac{\sum_i w_i^{(x)}w_i^{(y)}(x_i-\tilde{x})(y_i-\tilde{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_i (w_i^{(x)})^2(x_i-\tilde{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_i (w_i^{(y)})^2(y_i-\tilde{y})^2}}.$$ Fallbacks: (i) variables with \(\leq 2\) unique values \(\Rightarrow\) Pearson; (ii) \(\widehat{\mathrm{MAD}}\approx 0\) \(\Rightarrow\) Pearson.

5) Percentage Bend correlation (pbcor, Wilcox)

Using \(\beta\in[0,0.5]\), computes \(\widehat{W}\) as the \((1-\beta)\) quantile of absolute deviations from median; estimates \(\widehat{\phi}\) by adaptive trimming. Defines \(U=(x-\widehat{\phi})/\widehat{W}\), applies clipping \(\Psi(u)=\min(\max(u,-1),1)\), and normalizes: $$\mathrm{pbcor}(x,y)=\frac{\sum_i \Psi(U_i^{(x)})\Psi(U_i^{(y)})}{\sqrt{\sum_i \Psi(U_i^{(x)})^2}\sqrt{\sum_i \Psi(U_i^{(y)})^2}}\in[-1,1].$$

Input, output, and policies

  • Only numeric/logical columns are considered (logical \(\to\) {0,1}). Observations are combined pairwise (pairwise complete).

  • For each pair \((x,y)\), returns a data.frame with columns x, y and the statistics requested by the method argument.

  • Minimum sizes: MIN_PAIRS_COR=3 (Pearson/Spearman/Kendall/bicor/pbend); Hoeffding requires \(n\geq 5\).

Complexity and performance

  • Pearson/Spearman/Kendall: \(O(n)\) per pair (Kendall \(O(n^2)\) in naive form; suitable for moderate n).

  • Hoeffding (this version): \(O(n^2)\) per pair (computation of bivariate \(Q\) with weights). For large n, \(O(n\log n)\) versions are possible.

  • dCor: \(O(n^2)\) time and \(O(n)\) memory (without materialized \(n\times n\) matrices).

  • OpenMP: parallelizes over the space of variable pairs (outer loop).

Note

  • Values reported by hoeffding in this function follow the conventional 30× scale (Hmisc/SAS), facilitating comparisons.

  • distance returns the distance correlation (not the squared version); 0 indicates independence (under conditions), 1 indicates perfect dependence.

  • Results may differ from implementations that use "unbiased" variants (dCor) or alternative schemes for ranking/ties.

Best practices for usage and interpretation

  • Pearson: use when the relationship is plausibly linear and residuals ~ normal/homoscedastic. Outliers have large impact.

  • Spearman/Kendall: preferable for non-linear monotonicity and/or ordinal data. Kendall tends to be more interpretable as probability of concordance.

  • Hoeffding's D: ideal for non-monotonic dependencies (e.g., U-shaped relationships). 30× scale (Hmisc) facilitates comparison with usual reports.

  • dCor: measures strength of any association (0 indicates independence under conditions). Useful as multivariate screening.

  • bicor: robust to outliers; if variables are binary/discrete with \(\leq 2\) values, falling back to Pearson avoids artifacts.

  • pbcor: controls extreme influence via \(\beta\) (default \(\beta=0.2\)). Smaller \(\beta\) \(\Rightarrow\) less bending; larger \(\beta\) \(\Rightarrow\) greater robustness and potential efficiency loss under normality.

  • Inference: p-values and CIs are not returned; use specialized packages (e.g., Hmisc for Hoeffding, energy for dCor, WRS2 for robust methods).

Handling of extreme cases

  • If the number of valid pairs \(< 3\), returns NA_real_.

  • In bicor: if \(\widehat{\mathrm{MAD}}\approx 0\) (or few effective points after weighting), returns Pearson.

  • In pbend: if \(\widehat{W}\approx 0\) or adaptive trimming empties the core, returns NA_real_.

  • In hoeffding: requires \(n\geq 5\); otherwise NA_real_.

Examples


## Synthetic data
set.seed(123)
n  <- 120
x  <- rnorm(n)
yL <- 0.7*x + rnorm(n, sd=0.6)        # moderate linear relationship
yU <- (x^2) + rnorm(n, sd=0.4)        # U-shaped relationship (non-monotonic)
yO <- x; yO[sample(n, 5)] <- yO[sample(n, 5)] + 10  # outliers
df <- data.frame(x=x, yL=yL, yU=yU, yO=yO)

## 1) Complete panel
res_all <- OBCorr(df, method="all")
head(res_all)

## 2) Alternative methods (independence/non-linearity)
OBCorr(df, method="alternative")      # hoeffding + dCor

## 3) Robustness (outliers)
OBCorr(df, method="robust")           # bicor + pbend

## 4) Practical interpretation:
# - For (x, yL): High Pearson/Spearman/Kendall; high dCor; moderate/high Hoeffding.
# - For (x, yU): Pearson ~ 0; low Spearman; high dCor; high Hoeffding.
# - For (x, yO): Pearson degraded by outliers; bicor/pbend remain more stable.

## 5) Scaling with many variables
# Thread control (0 = auto)
OBCorr(df, method="distance", threads=0)

References

  • Hoeffding, W. (1948). A non-parametric test of independence. Annals of Mathematical Statistics, 19(4), 546–557.

  • Székely, G. J., Rizzo, M. L., & Bakirov, N. K. (2007). Measuring and testing dependence by correlation of distances. Annals of Statistics, 35(6), 2769–2794.

  • Székely, G. J., & Rizzo, M. L. (2013). The distance correlation t-test of independence in high dimension. Journal of Multivariate Analysis, 117, 193–213.

  • Langfelder, P., & Horvath, S. (2008). WGCNA: an R package for weighted correlation network analysis. BMC Bioinformatics, 9, 559.

  • Langfelder, P., & Horvath, S. (2012). Fast R Functions for Robust Correlations. (Notes from WGCNA package and bicor vignette.)

  • Wilcox, R. R. (2012/2017). Introduction to Robust Estimation and Hypothesis Testing. Academic Press.

  • Rizzo, M. L., & Székely, G. J. (2022). energy: E-statistics (energy statistics). CRAN package.

  • Harrell, F. E. Jr. (2024). Hmisc: Harrell Miscellaneous. CRAN package.

  • Mair, P., & Wilcox, R. R. (2020). WRS2: A Collection of Robust Statistical Methods. CRAN package.

See also

  • Hmisc::hoeffd (Hoeffding's D, 30× scale).

  • energy::dcor (Distance correlation).

  • WGCNA::bicor (Biweight midcorrelation).

  • WRS2::pbcor (Percentage bend correlation).
